“Sheltered at sea ” = ALEE: this is one of a number of similar clues answered by the same word, e.g. “Toward shelter, nautically” (1/5/98), “Toward shelter” (12/23/96, 9/23/98, 1/25/99, 12/25/06), “On the safe side, at sea” (3/31/98, 9/29/08), “On the safe side?” (7/26/99), “Sheltered, at sea” (3/22/00), “On the safe side” (10/13/99, 2/27/00), “Sheltered” (11/5/99, 8/17/02), “Protected, at sea” (10/2/05) = ALEE; “On the safe side” = LEEWARD (2/27/00). To be at sea is not just a figure of speech for mental confusion; it also means being completely exposed to the elements. There is no shelter or protection at sea, nor is there a safe side. “Alee” means “downwind;” cf. “Downwind” (1/21/97, 3/2/97), “Away from the wind” (5/12/05), “Downwind, to a sailor” (7/14/08) = ALEE. I used to work about a month a year on an oceanographic research vessel and spent a fair amount of time on weather deck obtaining data. I always wore knee-high rubber boots and a hard hat, and when the sea was up, rubber-ducky yellow Helly Hansens as well, thus being covered from head to toe with a waterproof membrane. One day, while collaborating with a winch operator on a CTD cast, I was hit full in the face by a wave that rolled horizontally over the afterdeck. The hood of my jacket and the hard hat channeled the water down the back of my neck so that my shirt was soaked. I had just finished thinking, at least my trousers are still dry, when the next wave came crashing down vertically and rebounded off the deck up my pant legs before cascading down into my boots, so that all my clothing was now sopping wet and my feet were immersed to ankle height by cold seawater. “Alee” may mean “safe” or “sheltered” in Topeka, Kansas, but not to those who go down to — or in — the sea in ships.

It used to be that monopoly and oligopoly providers of essential services were classified as utilities and regulated as such. However, through a devious strategy employing lobbyists, lawyers, and loot, the telcos and cable companies have managed to elude virtually every customary regulation of their activities.

Thus we have the FCC barred by the DC Circuit Appeals Court from regulating "internet services," services that look pretty identical to other cable services traveling the cable. Or the new AT&T -- formerly the virulently anti-regulation Southwestern Bell -- on the verge of recreating a wireless version of the old AT&T's landline monopoly by buying up T-Mobile, without visible opposition from the Justice Department.

Meanwhile, back in Sweden where I do a lot of work, I have 28Mbit/sec residential cable or 4G service for $20 a month, no caps) or 48Mbit/sec for $40. Smartphone service is comparable. If I want to, I can kick up my service to exceed 100Mbit/sec. No sweat. Swedes consider America an informational Third World country. With good reason. Our domestic situation is laughable.

Every time I see one of those AT&T ads crowing about serving the entire nation, or Comcast bragging about how it will offer all types of communications services, I cringe. I cannot imagine two worse shepherds of our nation's broadband infrastructure. Their competitors are only marginally better.

We have sewn ourselves into a straitjacket that not only is going to create market problems but decisively halt American innovation just when we need it the most. Our backward-looking country will continue its inexorable slide into irrelevance, helped by the very telecom companies that want us to believe they're helping out. Give us a break. You're sharks, just in it for the money. Or is it power? Or both? You're certainly not in it for your customers, country, or creativity.

If the point of the article is to encourage empathy/support for non-traditional families, I'm sure there are many non-traditional families that are not made up of neurotic narcissists. Those people seem quite wounded--never the best situation for becoming parents. Of course this also happens in traditional families, but this profile just gives ammunition to those who oppose non-traditional families.

I do think it is quite sad that fathers are starting to seem optional in today's families. Having been raised without one and having raised four children with a wonderful father, it makes a difference. Especially for boys--I believe this more now than I did before I watched my husband shepherd two boys to manhood.

#8--How about if you don't pay taxes for schools and the taxes my four kids will pay as adults don't contribute at all to your social security or Medicare? Fair is fair.

As an August '10 University of Michigan graduate, I am proud to say that I did not receive an apartment as a graduation gift, nor will I receive any other gifts exceeding the amount of my own tuition. I went to college so that I could obtain a job and support myself, as well as family. Instead of wanting my parents to give me a congratulatory gift, I hope that I will earn enough money to one day pay them back for all the sacrifices they made in order to fund my education. Even though these parents are presenting their children with one form of stability, they are discouraging them from being independent (one of the many lessons a college education emphasizes) and thus, handing them a form of instability. College is a time for growing up and for living life without the coddling and overprotectiveness of parents. It makes no sense to graduate and fall back into the bubble of being spoiled, even if money isn't an important factor. For many families, money is a viable topic of discussion, and now, with the economy the way it is, I am witnessing more people my age working long hours just to be able to buy food and survive.

I'm not a parent, but I get it. Parents typically will do anything they can, as much as they can, for their children.
However ... this at the extreme end -- the sums of money are astonishing -- and very hard to relate to. Not a lot of Americans have to worry about the $5 million gift exclusion, much less its expiration date! Agree with posters who say this is more about the gap between the haves and have-mores, and the complete neglect of the have-nothings.
My parents struggled financially their whole lives. Still, they went too easy on me, always. The 'deficits' I have had in my adult life are less financial (tho always a struggle also) but bigger 'life ticket' items -- job success (lack of confidence), relationships (poor choices), fear of failure, thus no sense of adventure, etc., etc.
Ultimately -- inevitably? -- a co-dependent relationship with the surviving parent and me developed, and while the love was there, always, both ways, the strings were always present also -- both ways.
And when she died, I was ... lost and adrift. 14 years later, still trying to fashion an identity and sense of self-worth.
Looking back, I wish the folks had pushed me more, encouraged me to branch out more, instead of implying, subtly, that they didn't trust me to make good choices, and thus I never learned to trust myself to try. That said, I realize they did their best and now it's up to me to improve my situation.
From my 50-something perch, the parents in this article are not 'helping' their children, except in the most literal ways and in so doing, are missing the bigger picture of the less-than-full life experience and life cycle they are potentially setting up for their kids.
I wish I could do it all over again, SO differently, and my bet is a lot of these 'gifted' kids will too.
Good luck to all.

The most important thing is that this little boy will be able to know who his real father is. Many fathers in traditional nuclear families are much more absent than the sperm donor Dad portrayed here. I urge the family not to put off telling the truth too long: even small children have a way of sensing untruth (even if presumably for their own good).

For me, the real take home here is that if families were more genuinely supported in the US, if there was something like real maternity leave, universl health insurance, excellent and affordable daycare, women would not have to delay childbearing.

I think the ratings are too high for every USA player except Howard.

The Reggae Boyz did not show up today (give credit to the USA keeping shape and packing midfield ) and the lack of tactics by Jamaica's Coach Whitmore who made Bob Bradley look competent, which is a scary thought.

The decision in not starting Donovan was already made before he went to his sister's wedding. The guy took a red eye to DC overnight and he knew he would not start today. Only the gullible press bought the lame "Bob made a great decision" angle. What nonsense.

A poster thinks that Michael Bradley is a great player? What?

He is the gaffer's son that is why he starts every match regardless of his performance.
Michael was average today as he is most of the time. This is a player that mostly sat on Aston Villa's bench this past season.

Jones's played well but was lucky not to get sent off for a cynical foul early and his dive was simply, disgraceful. I'd score it a 9.5, splash.

Dempsey was again average and Ricketts almost got to him before the showboating Clint scored.

If only Clint was as good as he thinks he is.

It is obvious Bradley and Jones need to play off each other better. They are too similar in style. Most of the time when they attempt to distribute the ball they give the ball back or make a poor pass. Why are both of them in? Why not Edu and Adu against Panama. Start a creative midfielder (Adu) that can dribble 5 yards. Jones already has a yellow. Any bets how quickly he gets carded against Panama?

Goodson is a nightmare in waiting, again. Cherundolo played well as did Boca.
Lichaj's score was too high and he is pretty green. I can see him getting skinned against Panama.

Bedoya played well but Kjlestan was way over rated. An 8? Come on. They both got width but only one goal was scored today by a USA player. Remember that.

Panama must be happy they got the Yanks again. Their forwards will hound the USA backline and they will stack the midfield just like they did in the Group match.

Seemingly the USA can get revenge. They were played off the pitch last Saturday by Panama. They probably cannot play that poorly again, or can they?

May the best side win.

I'm glad the USA won after playing awfully in the group stages and even this game. We gave Jamaica way too many opportunities and were lucky they didn't score. I hope that this is a sign of brighter plays to come.

However, with Jones... Yes, he contributed a lot to this game and even scored, own goal or not. However, the way he picked up his yellow card and his diving to get the opponent sent off... That was unprofessional by all means and just for that, my rating for him will go down to a 6.5, 7 if I'm being generous. Yes, I want the US to win and sometimes players need to play dirty to gain the slightest of advantages, but that was unnecessary. I'm frankly a bit disappointed Jones played like this.

Yesterday I was returning from Pittsburgh to New York by Mega Bus. There were  many 11th graders in the Bus. I taught to some  how to play a scrabble type of game for  improving their English knowledge. They hardly played for 5 minutes. Then I demonstrated Speed Multiplication pertaining to Ancient Indian Maths called Vedic Mathematics in 2 to 3 minutes. One student said WOW. During the demonstration I asked her what is 997 - 9 . She did not know the answer. She saw the examples for couple of minutes and kept it in her bag. I asked them how many yards are there in a mile?. I told them there are 1760 yards in a mile. They did not know the answer. So they searched on the internet and got the answer and again said WOW. Now I know for sure the malady of America. Incidently the journey between Pittsburgh and New York is 8 hours. They spent most of their time gossiping, cell phone talking and either cell phone text reading or texting. This  is  not to belittle anybody but sincerely feel sorry for future of America. It is high time. Let all the People concerned stand united in this present worst crisis and do something constructive for the Bright Future of America.

How about the parallel to electricity? You pay what you consume. Providers can ask for something reasonable, like 10 cents per gigabyte of transfer. This would open the door for more expensive peek tariff and you would be able to optimize the consumption.

There are limits to the cloud model.  Internet service was out for weeks in much of Houston after Hurricane Ike.  Ditto Japan after the tsunami.  Do you really want all of your information to be inaccessible when you are dealing with an emergency?  No, but because of the economies of cloud computing during ordinary times, things like medical records, directories and instruction manuals are increasingly moving to remote centralized locations accessible only by network (i.e. the cloud).
